heading: riaa may sue lycos over mp3
subheading: the recording industry association of america said it may take legal action against the search engine that links to mp3 files.
author: reuters
text: frustrated in its negotiations with lycos over the company's use of a controversial online audio technology, the us recording industry said late wednesday it is considering a lawsuit against the internet portal. we're looking at all our options, including litigation, the recording industry association of america said.on wednesday, lycos' norwegian joint venture partner was sued over alleged copyright infringement by the london-based international federation of the phonographic industry.lycos (lcos) said earlier on wednesday that it had not seen a lawsuit and was continuing to negotiate with the riaa.lycos launched a service using the technology and database of norway's fast search & transfer asa to offer links to more than half a million online recorded songs.the music is available through a popular and controversial technology called mp3, which allow fans to download near-cd quality songs from the internet onto computers or mp3 players. the recording industry is concerned because the technology allows for both legitimate and pirated use of music."we haven't seen the complaint," said lycos spokesman brian payea.he said that shortly after lycos launched its joint venture, it was contacted by the recording industry association of america."we continue to work with the riaa here, as we said we would," payea said.lycos is in the process of buying the parent company of wired news.copyright
